name: HD 164922 - Oldest Star With a Planetary System
scenarioDescription:
The HD 164922 Exoplanetary System

HD 164922 is a star with 0.93 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.95 times its radius. It is located 71.75 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 9.58 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 164922 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

HD 164922 b

HD 164922 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2006-07. Its semi-major axis is 2.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 1207.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 164922.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.08, which means that when HD 164922 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 1.99 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 2.33. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 164922 b is 115.99 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 164922 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

HD 164922 d

HD 164922 d was discovered by the Roque de los Muchachos Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-05. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.46 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 164922.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.12, which means that when HD 164922 d is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.09 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.12. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 164922 d is 4.00 times the mass of Earth. At 4.00 Earth masses, HD 164922 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

HD 164922 c

HD 164922 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2016-10. Its semi-major axis is 0.34 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 75.74 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, HD 164922.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.12, which means that when HD 164922 c is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.30 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.38. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of HD 164922 c is 13.00 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, HD 164922 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 164922, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by W. M. Keck Observatory.
